elements.content: Template directed synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is of increasing interest. Herein we report the synthesis of six new MOFs synthesized from 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) and InCl3. The new frameworks are formally two- (YCM-21) and one-dimensional (YCM-22) anionic, as well as three-dimensional neutral (YCM-23). YCM-22 contains an unprecedented dianionic [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2– node. The structural diversity represented by these materials is entirely controlled by addition of organic ammonium salts during the synthesis process. The role of the additives is briefly discussed with observed correlations of (1) hydrogen bonding and cation−π interactions influencing MOF dimensionality and (2) the presence of anionic chlorides creating a chlorine-rich metal center leading to a one-dimensional framework.

Herein we report the synthesis of six new MOFs synthesized from 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) and InCl3. The new frameworks are formally two- (YCM-21) and one-dimensional (YCM-22) anionic, as well as three-dimensional neutral (YCM-23). YCM-22 contains an unprecedented dianionic [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2- node. The structural diversity represented by these materials is entirely controlled by addition of organic ammonium salts during the synthesis process. The role of the additives is briefly discussed with observed correlations of (1) hydrogen bonding and cation-π interactions influencing MOF dimensionality and (2) the presence of anionic chlorides creating a chlorine-rich metal center leading to a one-dimensional framework.

elements.content: Treatment of InCl3 and 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of a series of organic ammonium salts yielded six new MOFs. These MOFs range from 2-D and 1-D anionic frameworks to 3-D neutral frameworks. In the five new anionic structures, the guest cation−MOF interactions were characterized via X-ray crystallography and are discussed herein.

In the five new anionic structures, the guest cation-MOF interactions were characterized via X-ray crystallography and are discussed herein.

elements.content: As metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) become increasingly more diverse and targeted applications become more prevalent, the ability to control and predict the supramolecular structure of these materials a priori is of increasing importance. Significant results have originated from Yaghi’s “reticular synthesis” approach that defines the inorganic node (a.k.a., secondary building unit (SBU)) as a rigid hub and the organic linker as a rigid spoke connecting two or more hubs together. Further advances have been realized by Ferey’s controlled SBU technique in which the individual SBU is synthesized prior to MOF synthesis and used as a “seed” for crystal growth, effectively directing the type of framework synthesized. The assumption of a rigid SBU is vital to the predictive nature of this model, rendering this approach challenging for MOFs with nonrigid or structurally flexible SBUs. This challenge is most evident when the SBU is a single metal atom because the metal center can adopt myriad coordination modes and geometries, leading to drastic changes in framework architecture.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) become increasingly more diverse and targeted applications become more prevalent, the ability to control and predict the supramolecular structure of these materials a priori is of increasing importance. Significant results have originated from Yaghi's "reticular synthesis" approach that defines the inorganic node (a.k.a., secondary building unit (SBU)) as a rigid hub and the organic linker as a rigid spoke connecting two or more hubs together. Further advances have been realized by Ferey's controlled SBU technique in which the individual SBU is synthesized prior to MOF synthesis and used as a "seed" for crystal growth, effectively directing the type of framework synthesized. The assumption of a rigid SBU is vital to the predictive nature of this model, rendering this approach challenging for MOFs with nonrigid or structurally flexible SBUs. This challenge is most evident when the SBU is a single metal atom because the metal center can adopt myriad coordination modes and geometries, leading to drastic changes in framework architecture.

elements.content: Indium­(III) centered MOFs have become an attractive target due to the ability of In­(III) to bind up to six X-type ligands to attain an overall negative three formal charge, allowing for the synthesis of charge neutral, anionic, and cationic frameworks. This diversity in coordination chemistry of In­(III) centers offers the potential for the synthesis of equally diverse In-centered MOFs. Traditionally, In-derived MOFs adopt one of three “standard” SBUs: monomeric [In­(O2CR)4]−, infinite chain [In­(μ-O2CR)2(μ-OH)]∞, and trimeric {In3O­(O2CR)6(H2O)3]+ (). Although other In-derived SBU’s have been reported, the full gamut of In coordination chemistry has yet to be realized in MOF architectures, especially with nodes possessing a formal anionic charge.
elements.clean_text: Indium(III) centered MOFs have become an attractive target due to the ability of In(III) to bind up to six X-type ligands to attain an overall negative three formal charge, allowing for the synthesis of charge neutral, anionic, and cationic frameworks. This diversity in coordination chemistry of In(III) centers offers the potential for the synthesis of equally diverse In-centered MOFs. Traditionally, In-derived MOFs adopt one of three "standard" SBUs: monomeric [In(O2CR)4]-, infinite chain [In(μ-O2CR)2(μ-OH)]∞, and trimeric {In3O(O2CR)6(H2O)3]+ (). Although other In-derived SBU's have been reported, the full gamut of In coordination chemistry has yet to be realized in MOF architectures, especially with nodes possessing a formal anionic charge.

elements.content: Since the [In­(O2CR)4]− SBU is anionic, it is associated with charge-balancing cations deposited during the synthesis process, which are often themselves products of solvent decomposition. The role of such cations during MOF formation is not yet fully understood, but it is known that the type of cation can have a significant impact on pore architecture and diversity, leading to a potential template effect. Template-controlled MOF synthesis has been well studied and reviewed extensively. In the synthesis of anionic MOFs, N-centered cations (ammonium ions) are often the template of choice, since they are chemically robust, are easily synthesized, have the potential to be chiral, and can be strong hydrogen bond donors. Given the potential for diverse impacts of such cations on MOF synthesis, we hypothesized that a series of unique frameworks could be synthesized from the same starting inorganic and organic building blocks in which the structural outcome was controlled by changing the templating cation. To this end, 2,5-thiophene dicarboxylic acid (TDC) was chosen as the organic linker and InCl3 was chosen as the inorganic node precursor in these studies. Previously Bu has demonstrated that this recipe yields homochiral ATF-1, a 3-dimensional interpenetrated MOF. Enantioselective synthesis of ATF-1 was realized by adding the chiral alkaloid cinchonine to the reaction mixture.

elements.content: One could imagine that the templating cation could interact with the as-synthesized MOF in one of five possible motifs highlighted in . If the templating cation were a hydrogen bond donor (HBD), then the cation could hydrogen bond to one of the oxygens on the carboxylate linkers (motif 1), the anionic metal center (motif 2), or the non-π electrons of thiophene (motif 3). If a non-HBD were used, then one could imagine a Lewis base–cation interaction (motif 4) or a cation−π interaction (motif 5). Herein we report the synthesis of four unique anionic 2-D MOFs, one anionic 1-D MOF, and one neutral 3-D MOF derived from TDC and In­(III) in which the dimensionality of the corresponding structures was greatly influenced by exogenous templating salts.

elements.content: 2,5-Thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) was purchased from TCI-America, InCl3 was purchased from Alfa Aesar, tetraethylammonium bromide and cinchonine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and all solvents were purchased from Acros. All purchased reagents were used as received. Syntheses and characterization data for triethylbutylammonium bromide (TEBA), N-spirocyclicmorpholiniumpyrole bromide (spMP), N-spirocyclicpiperidiniumpyrole bromide (spPP), and ATF-1 can be found in the Supporting Information. CCDC 1439149 to 1439155 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

2,5-Thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) was purchased from TCI-America, InCl3 was purchased from Alfa Aesar, tetraethylammonium bromide and cinchonine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and all solvents were purchased from Acros. All purchased reagents were used as received. Syntheses and characterization data for triethylbutylammonium bromide (TEBA), N-spirocyclicmorpholiniumpyrole bromide (spMP), N-spirocyclicpiperidiniumpyrole bromide (spPP), and ATF-1 can be found in the Supporting Information. CCDC 1439149 to 1439155 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

elements.content: To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.620 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv), followed by ammonium cation (1.10 mmol, 1.77 equiv) and 2 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 10 min until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions, into 6 individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

General Synthesis for the YCM-21 Series

To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.620 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv), followed by ammonium cation (1.10 mmol, 1.77 equiv) and 2 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 10 min until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions, into 6 individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.

The resulting mixture was sonicated for 10 min until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions into five individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 6 days. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was then decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.

elements.content: To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.620 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv). In a separate vial, cinchonine (324 mg, 1.10 mmol, 1.77 equiv), 3 mL of deionized water, and 0.050 mL of concentrated HNO3 were mixed, and the entire vial was sonicated until all solids were dissolved. The contents of the vial was then added to the DMF mixture, and the entire solution was sonicated for 10 min. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions into six individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.

elements.content: Initial efforts began with the treatment of InCl3 (2.13 equiv) and TDC (1.00 equiv) in a mixture of DMF/1,4-dioxane/water with conc. HNO3 as an additive at 120 °C yielding the previously reported homochiral ATF-1 (). The DMF/1,4-dioxane/water mixture has been shown to be a privileged solvent recipe for formation of anionic MOFs because it leads to the in situ formation of Me2NH2 +, which is putatively accelerated by the addition of conc. HNO3. X-ray analysis was consistent with previous reports confirming that ATF-1 is an anionic, three-dimensional interpenetrated structure with two unique intercatenated frameworks. The In-center is distorted-tetrahedral with cis In–In–In angles of 83.7°, 97.7°, 98.7°, and 113.3° and trans angles of 131.0° and 133.8°. The Me2NH2 + cation is doubly hydrogen bonded to the O-carboxylate (motif-1) with H-bond distances of 2.1 and 2.8 Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Description

Initial efforts began with the treatment of InCl3 (2.13 equiv) and TDC (1.00 equiv) in a mixture of DMF/1,4-dioxane/water with conc. HNO3 as an additive at 120 °C yielding the previously reported homochiral ATF-1 (). The DMF/1,4-dioxane/water mixture has been shown to be a privileged solvent recipe for formation of anionic MOFs because it leads to the in situ formation of Me2NH2 +, which is putatively accelerated by the addition of conc. HNO3. X-ray analysis was consistent with previous reports confirming that ATF-1 is an anionic, three-dimensional interpenetrated structure with two unique intercatenated frameworks. The In-center is distorted-tetrahedral with cis In-In-In angles of 83.7°, 97.7°, 98.7°, and 113.3° and trans angles of 131.0° and 133.8°. The Me2NH2 + cation is doubly hydrogen bonded to the O-carboxylate (motif-1) with H-bond distances of 2.1 and 2.8 Å, respectively.

Note solvent and disorder have been omitted for clarity.

Synthetic efforts then focused on substituting the HNO3 in the starting ATF-1 synthesis with ammonium cations to achieve different architectural outcomes of the framework itself. To this end, we treated InCl3 (2.13 equiv) and TDC (1.00 equiv) with varying quaternary ammonium cations (1.77 equiv) in a mixture of DMF/1,4-dioxane/water (A). All noncommercially available cations were synthesized via N-alkylation of the corresponding amines with the appropriate alkyl halide. Under the identified conditions, the quaternary ammonium salts tetraethylammonium (TEA), triethylbutylammonium (TEBA), N-spirocyclicmorpholiniumpyrole (spMP), and N-spirocyclicpiperidiniumpyrole (spPP), all in the form of their respective bromides, were successfully implemented as template molecules (B), yielding four unique two-dimensional anionic MOFs hereto referred as YCM-21-Z (YCM = Youngstown Crystalline Material), where Z is the templating cation. All four MOF syntheses yielded single crystalline material suitable for full structural analysis, the results of which are highlighted below.

All noncommercially available cations were synthesized via N-alkylation of the corresponding amines with the appropriate alkyl halide. Under the identified conditions, the quaternary ammonium salts tetraethylammonium (TEA), triethylbutylammonium (TEBA), N-spirocyclicmorpholiniumpyrole (spMP), and N-spirocyclicpiperidiniumpyrole (spPP), all in the form of their respective bromides, were successfully implemented as template molecules (B), yielding four unique two-dimensional anionic MOFs hereto referred as YCM-21-Z (YCM = Youngstown Crystalline Material), where Z is the templating cation. elements.content: The YCM-21 series is composed of two-dimensional checkerboard-like sheets arranged in A–B or A–B–A′–B′ repeating patterns (– ), where each individual “square” pore of the sheet is approximately 10.2 Å × 10.2 Å. In contrast to ATF-1, the In center in the YCM-21 is square planar with average cis In–In–In angles of ca. 90° and trans angles of 180°. YCM-21-TEA and -TEBA both have angles that deviate from the ideal 90°, with cis angles of 93.6° and 86.4° (TEA) and 97.0 and 83.0 (TEBA) respectively, while YCM-21-spPP and -spMP have ideal 90° cis angles. YCM-21-TEA and -TEBA are isomorphous and thus feature nearly identical two-dimensional structures with A–B repeating patterns, with the only difference being minor deviations in In–In–In angles and layer spacing. With the exception of YCM-21-spMP, which contains disordered DMF, the YCM-21 series is crystallographically devoid of solvent. In YCM-21-spMP, the void space in c is occupied by disordered DMF. We postulate that the presence of solvent in YCM-21-spMP leads to the increase in spacing between the layers (see ) compared with the other members of the YCM-21 series.

Crystallographically, the templating cations reside in the center of the individual “squares” of the checkerboard. depicts a side-on view of each of the four pores of the YCM-21 series, depicting cation−π interactions of the cation with the thiophene ring (motif 5). Although YCM-21-TEA and YCM-21-spPP appear to have S-centered stacking interactions, if these interactions were truly Lewis base–cation (motif 4), one would expect the cations to be coplanar with the thiophene ring instead of orthogonal. This is consistent with the literature because thiophene tends to bind cationic Lewis acid metal centers η5 (motif 5) instead of S-bound (motif 4).

elements.content: The YCM-21 series represents four unique structures that, although comprised of topologically identical two-dimensional sheets, differ greatly in how they are assembled. Isomorphous YCM-21-TEA and -TEBA are the only MOFs in this series with an A–B–A–B repeating pattern, while the other two structures have an A–B–A′–B′ repeating pattern, in which the A′–B′ layers are vertically and horizontally offset from their A–B counterparts. Since the only difference between the materials in the series is the endogenous cation, it is reasonable to assume that the cation is the cause for the shift in the two-dimensional layers. It is noteworthy that the subtle change between TEA and TEBA do not yield dramatic differences in framework architecture. Geometrically the spPP and spMP cations are nearly identical but electronically distinct due to the extra O atom present in spMP. This electronic distinction appears to be critical in MOF architectural determination; however, the exact mechanism of action for the synthetic differentiation in the YCM-21 series remains unclear at this time.

Since the only difference between the materials in the series is the endogenous cation, it is reasonable to assume that the cation is the cause for the shift in the two-dimensional layers. It is noteworthy that the subtle change between TEA and TEBA do not yield dramatic differences in framework architecture. Geometrically the spPP and spMP cations are nearly identical but electronically distinct due to the extra O atom present in spMP. This electronic distinction appears to be critical in MOF architectural determination; however, the exact mechanism of action for the synthetic differentiation in the YCM-21 series remains unclear at this time.

elements.content: Chemically, the nodes for ATF-1 and the YCM-21 series are both [In­(TDC)4]− moieties with the only major difference being the geometry of the In center when incorporated into the framework. The factors that govern this differentiation remain to be elucidated; however, it is clear that in the presence of non-hydrogen-bonding cations, the two-dimensional series is obtained. When cations with two hydrogen bond donors are involved (Me2NH2 + and Et2NH2 +), the three-dimensional structure is synthesized. We postulate that through hydrogen bonding to the carboxylate functionality of the linker, Me2NH2 + distorts the In center to the pseudotetrahedral geometry (the In–In–In angle of the quadrant containing the cation is 98.7°) through both steric and electrostatic interactions yielding the ATF-1 architecture. The quaternary ammonium cations of the YCM-21 series do not allow for any hydrogen bonding and are devoid of all interactions with the In center itself, allowing for the In center to adopt a symmetrical square planar geometry.

The quaternary ammonium cations of the YCM-21 series do not allow for any hydrogen bonding and are devoid of all interactions with the In center itself, allowing for the In center to adopt a symmetrical square planar geometry.

elements.content: ATF-1 is synthesized in the presence of a cation with two hydrogen bond donors, while the YCM-21 series is synthesized in the presence of cations with no hydrogen bond donors. In an effort to study the effects of cations with single hydrogen bond donors, InCl3 (2.13 equiv) and TDC (1.00 equiv) were treated with pyridinium chloride (1.77 equiv) in a mixture of DMF/1,4-dioxane/water. This resulted in a mixture containing ATF-1 and a new one-dimensional MOF (YCM-22) with a dianonic [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2– node and two charge balancing Me2NH2 + counterions. Due to the chloride-rich nature of the new SBU, it was hypothesized that pyridinium chloride was serving as a HCl surrogate during the synthesis process. To this end, when pyridinium chloride was replaced with conc. HCl, clean formation of YCM-22 () was observed. YCM-22 contains a pseudotrigonal bipyramidal node with two TDC molecules and one chloride in equatorial positions and two chlorides in the axial positions. Irrespective of whether YCM-22 is grown in the presence of pyridinium chloride or conc. HCl, the counterion is always Me2NH2 + hydrogen bonded to the equatorial chloride at a distance of 2.5 Å.

elements.content: YCM-22 represents, to our knowledge, an unprecedented [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2– node. We hypothesize that the excess chloride present in solution prevents dissociation of the In–Cl bonds leading to the pentacoordinate In center. This type of node is not just uncommon in MOF literature but appears to be unknown in In coordination chemistry as a whole. The potential for synthesizing other unprecedented structures containing dianionic indium nodes with five X-type ligands is encouraging and under further investigation by our group.

We hypothesize that the excess chloride present in solution prevents dissociation of the In-Cl bonds leading to the pentacoordinate In center. This type of node is not just uncommon in MOF literature but appears to be unknown in In coordination chemistry as a whole. The potential for synthesizing other unprecedented structures containing dianionic indium nodes with five X-type ligands is encouraging and under further investigation by our group.

elements.content: Lastly, when we treated InCl3 (2.13 equiv) and TDC (1.00 equiv) in DMF/dioxane/water with premixed cinchonine (1.77 equiv) and conc. HNO3 acid, a new three-dimensional neutral MOF with an infinite chain SBU [In­(μ-O2CR)2(μ-OH)]∞ (YCM-23) was obtained (). The infinite chains are linked together through the individual carboxylates of the TDC linkages, in which each carboxylate binds two indium centers and each organic linker binds two individual chains, respectively. Although a common SBU in indium chemistry, this infinite chain differs from the only other previously reported In–TDC infinite chain structure, which had an [In­(κ2-O2CR)2(μ-OH)­(H2O)]∞ SBU. These results were striking since it was previously reported that addition of cinchonine to the original ATF-1 synthesis (In­(NO3)3, TDC, DMF) resulted in the formation of enantiomerically pure ATF-1. It is noteworthy that neither free cinchonine nor the protonated cinchonium salt are present in either ATF-1 or YCM-23. Despite the lack of presence in the final structure, we postulate that there is a distinct mechanistic difference between the neutral cinchonine as used in the ATF-1 synthesis and cationic cinchonium nitrate employed in the YCM-23 synthesis. At the present time, this effect has not been completely elucidated and is the subject of further investigation.

YCM-23 is porous in all three Cartesian coordinates, with the largest pore being 9.9 Å × 10.9 Å with a space-filling window of 5.7 Å × 5.4 Å. PLATON calculations reveal a guest accessible void volume of 51%. Crystallographically the void space is occupied with disordered DMF. Attempts to attain a BET surface area were unsuccessful due to the instability of the YCM-23 framework upon removal of the DMF from the pores.

elements.content: To establish whether the YCM-21 structures were unique or dynamically interchangeable, depending on the cation present, YCM-21-TEBA was suspended for 1 week in a DMF solution of spPPBr. After this time, PXRD analysis showed no change in the diffraction pattern (Figure S11). When YCM-21-spPP was treated with a DMF solution of TEBABr, after 1 week PXRD analysis also indicated no change in the bulk material (Figure S12). NMR analysis of the digested MOFs postreaction indicated that less than 6% cation exchange had occurred. This is most likely due to the small aperture sizes and distances between the layers for the YCM-21 series, prohibiting endogenous cation exchange (). Additionally we demonstrated that the entire YCM-21 series is incapable of Li+ uptake. Each of the YCM-21 materials were suspended in a DMF/acetone (1:1 vol) solution of Li­[BF4] for 3 days. After soaking in Li+ solution, each of the YCM-21 materials was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) as well as PXRD. PXRD analysis indicated that no structural changes occurred upon soaking in the Li+ solution. Due to its small ionic radii, Li+ is kinetically capable of accessing the voids between the two-dimensional layers of the YCM-21 series. Failure to observe Li+ uptake implies that the endogenous organic cations could be too large to be removed from the YCM-21 series. These data, in conjunction with the ammonium cation exchange experiments, imply that the YCM-21 structures are unique and are not interchangeable albeit due to lack of cation exchange ability.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Property Analysis

To establish whether the YCM-21 structures were unique or dynamically interchangeable, depending on the cation present, YCM-21-TEBA was suspended for 1 week in a DMF solution of spPPBr. After this time, PXRD analysis showed no change in the diffraction pattern (Figure S11). When YCM-21-spPP was treated with a DMF solution of TEBABr, after 1 week PXRD analysis also indicated no change in the bulk material (Figure S12). NMR analysis of the digested MOFs postreaction indicated that less than 6% cation exchange had occurred. This is most likely due to the small aperture sizes and distances between the layers for the YCM-21 series, prohibiting endogenous cation exchange (). Additionally we demonstrated that the entire YCM-21 series is incapable of Li+ uptake. Each of the YCM-21 materials were suspended in a DMF/acetone (1:1 vol) solution of Li[BF4] for 3 days. After soaking in Li+ solution, each of the YCM-21 materials was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) as well as PXRD. PXRD analysis indicated that no structural changes occurred upon soaking in the Li+ solution. Due to its small ionic radii, Li+ is kinetically capable of accessing the voids between the two-dimensional layers of the YCM-21 series. Failure to observe Li+ uptake implies that the endogenous organic cations could be too large to be removed from the YCM-21 series. These data, in conjunction with the ammonium cation exchange experiments, imply that the YCM-21 structures are unique and are not interchangeable albeit due to lack of cation exchange ability.

elements.content: All new MOFs were tested for stability in the following solvents at room temperature for 7 days: EtOH, CH3CN, H2O, AcOH, 1 M HCl(aq), and 1 M NaOH(aq). The results are summarized in . Notably ATF-1, the entire YCM-21 series, and YCM-23 all undergo a phase transition in the presence of 1 M HCl to an as yet unidentified common crystalline product (Figure S7). The lowest angle peak observed in the diffraction patterns are at 15° 2θ, implying that this common product is most likely not a MOF due to the decrease in unit-cell dimensions. Strikingly, YCM-21-TEA was the only MOF stable in 1 M NaOH(aq) solution. YCM-22 was stable in CH3CN but began to undergo partial phase change in the presence of EtOH and full phase change to an as yet identified crystalline product in the presence of H2O.

In summary, we have reported six new metal–organic frameworks derived from InCl3 and TDC. The new frameworks are formally two- (YCM-21) and one-dimensional (YCM-22) anionic, as well as three-dimensional neutral (YCM-23). Synthesis of these unique structures and thus the architectural outcomes of the reaction were influenced via the addition of organic ammonium salts to the reaction mixture. Quaternary ammonium cations with no hydrogen bond donors consistently produced anionic two-dimensional YCM-21 derivatives. In all four structures, the guest cation is participating in cation−π interactions with the aromatic linkage. We propose that the cation−π interaction (motif 5) leads to the two-dimensional framework whereas the H-bonding in ATF-1 (motif 1) forces the formation of the three-dimensional framework by altering the geometry of the indium center. The presence of excess chloride yielded one-dimensional dianionic YCM-22 containing an unprecedented [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2– node. We postulate that this novel node will serve as an entry point in the synthesis of new anionic In-derived MOFs. Although our preliminary data suggest an initial understanding of the interactions of cations with the synthesized MOF frameworks, detailed mechanistic roles of each template molecule during MOF synthesis remain to be elucidated. These studies are currently being investigated, and those results will be disclosed when appropriate.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have reported six new metal-organic frameworks derived from InCl3 and TDC. The new frameworks are formally two- (YCM-21) and one-dimensional (YCM-22) anionic, as well as three-dimensional neutral (YCM-23). Synthesis of these unique structures and thus the architectural outcomes of the reaction were influenced via the addition of organic ammonium salts to the reaction mixture. Quaternary ammonium cations with no hydrogen bond donors consistently produced anionic two-dimensional YCM-21 derivatives. In all four structures, the guest cation is participating in cation-π interactions with the aromatic linkage. We propose that the cation-π interaction (motif 5) leads to the two-dimensional framework whereas the H-bonding in ATF-1 (motif 1) forces the formation of the three-dimensional framework by altering the geometry of the indium center. The presence of excess chloride yielded one-dimensional dianionic YCM-22 containing an unprecedented [InCl3(κ2-O2CAr)2]2- node. We postulate that this novel node will serve as an entry point in the synthesis of new anionic In-derived MOFs. Although our preliminary data suggest an initial understanding of the interactions of cations with the synthesized MOF frameworks, detailed mechanistic roles of each template molecule during MOF synthesis remain to be elucidated. These studies are currently being investigated, and those results will be disclosed when appropriate.

To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.620 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv), followed by ammonium cation (1.10 mmol, 1.77 equiv) and 2 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 10 min until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions, into 6 individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.

Synthesis of YCM-22

To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.62 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv), followed by concentrated HCl (0.034 mL) and 2 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 10 min until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions into five individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 6 days. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was then decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.

Synthesis of YCM-23

To a premixed solution of DMF (18 mL) and dioxane (12 mL) was added 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (107 mg, 0.620 mmol, 1.00 equiv) and InCl3 (291 mg, 1.32 mmol, 2.13 equiv). In a separate vial, cinchonine (324 mg, 1.10 mmol, 1.77 equiv), 3 mL of deionized water, and 0.050 mL of concentrated HNO3 were mixed, and the entire vial was sonicated until all solids were dissolved. The contents of the vial was then added to the DMF mixture, and the entire solution was sonicated for 10 min. The resulting solution was then filtered through a GE 25 mm PVDF syringe filter (0.45 μm) in 6 mL portions into six individual 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were sealed with Teflon-lined caps and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. The vials were then removed from the oven and were set aside to cool to room temperature. The contents of each individual vial were combined and washed with 3 × 10 mL portions of fresh DMF. The DMF was decanted, and the crystals were activated by drying overnight under vacuum at 100 °C.
